importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of the expulsion of two top generals, a significant development in China’s anti-corruption campaign.
The anti-corruption drive in the People’s Liberation Army began in 2023, establishing a timeline for the ongoing purge of military officials.
In August 2022, U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan prompted live-fire drills, with He Weidong playing a key role in planning these exercises, highlighting his strategic importance.
He Weidong was promoted to vice-chair of the Central Military Commission in 2022, bypassing the Central Committee, signaling a significant advancement in his political influence.
The announcement comes just days before the Fourth Plenum of the Communist Party Central Committee, when new personnel decisions are expected to be formalized.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The anti-corruption campaign in the PLA began in 2023, and the expulsions in October 2025 mark a continuation and escalation of that campaign, showing a sustained political effort.

keyTakeAways: He Weidong and Miao Hua, two of the most senior military officials, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army due to corruption charges.
This is the first time a sitting general has been expelled from the Central Military Commission since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution, indicating a significant shift in military governance.

He Weidong, a close associate of President Xi Jinping, previously commanded the Eastern Theatre in Fujian province, a region directly facing Taiwan, and played a key role in planning aggressive live-fire drills after Pelosi’s visit in 2022.
The purge reflects President Xi Jinping’s broader effort to 'clean house' within the military and political leadership, particularly ahead of the Fourth Plenum of the Central Committee.
Many of the purged officials, including former political commissars and commanders, have been absent from public view for months, suggesting a covert anti-corruption drive.
The expulsion of He Weidong, who held a seat on the Politburo, has implications beyond the military, as it affects the political balance within the ruling Communist Party.
The Central Military Commission, which has been half-empty since March, is expected to see new appointments during the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, China's defense ministry announced the expulsion of two top military officials, He Weidong and Miao Hua, from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army due to corruption charges. He Weidong, who served as the second-highest-ranking general and held a seat on the Politburo, is the first sitting general to be expelled from the Central Military Commission since the Cultural Revolution. Miao Hua, previously investigated and removed in June 2025, is also targeted. The purge is part of a broader anti-corruption drive initiated in 2023 and aligns with President Xi Jinping’s campaign to 'clean house' within the military and political leadership. The removals are particularly significant as they occur just before the Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, where new appointments are expected. He Weidong’s close ties to Xi Jinping, including their service in Fujian province and his role in planning aggressive drills after Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan in 2022, underscore the strategic and political implications of the purge. The campaign extends to other senior officials, including former political commissars and joint command leaders, and reflects a deepening structural shift in China’s military and party governance.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
